id.desc: Component ID, not specified by default. If specified, it can be used to refer the component in option or API.

name.desc:
Series name used for displaying in [tooltip][0] and filtering with [legend][1], or updating data and configuration with setOption.

[0]: #tooltip
[1]: #legend

coordinateSystem.desc:
The coordinate used in the series, whose options are: 

* 'cartesian2d' Use a two-dimensional rectangular coordinate (also known as Cartesian coordinate), with [xAxisIndex][0] and [yAxisIndex][1] to assign the corresponding axis component.

* 'geo' Use geographic coordinate, with [geoIndex][2] to assign the corresponding geographic coordinate components.



[0]: #series-heatmap.xAxisIndex
[1]: #series-heatmap.yAxisIndex
[2]: #series-heatmap.geoIndex

xAxisIndex.desc:
Index of [x axis][0] to combine with, which is useful for multiple x axes in one chart.

[0]: #xAxis

yAxisIndex.desc:
Index of [y axis][0] to combine with, which is useful for multiple y axes in one chart.

[0]: #yAxis

geoIndex.desc:
Index of [geographic coordinate][0] to combine with, which is useful for multiple geographic axes in one chart.

[0]: #geo

calendarIndex.desc:
Index of [calendar coordinates][0] to combine with, which is useful for multiple calendar coordinates in one chart.

[0]: #calendar

pointSize.desc:
Point size of each data point. It is valid with [coordinateSystem][0] of 'geo' value.

[0]: #series-heatmap.coordinateSystem

blurSize.desc:
Blur size of each data point. It is valid with [coordinateSystem][0] of 'geo' value.

[0]: #series-heatmap.coordinateSystem

minOpacity.desc:
Minimum opacity. It is valid with [coordinateSystem][0] of 'geo' value.

[0]: #series-heatmap.coordinateSystem

maxOpacity.desc:
Maximum opacity. It is valid with [coordinateSystem][0] of 'geo' value.

[0]: #series-heatmap.coordinateSystem

progressive.desc: progressive specifies the amount of graphic elements that can be rendered within a frame (about 16ms) if "progressive rendering" enabled. When data amount is from thousand to more than 10 million, it will take too long time to render all of the graphic elements. Since ECharts 4, "progressive rendering" is supported in its workflow, which processes and renders data chunk by chunk alone with each frame, avoiding to block the UI thread of the browser. Set progressive: 0 to disable progressive permanently. By default, progressive is auto-enabled when data amount is bigger than progressiveThreshold.

progressiveThreshold.desc: If current data amount is over the threshold, "progressive rendering" is enabled.

label.position.desc:
Label position. **Followings are the options:*** [x, y] Use relative percentage, or absolute pixel values to represent position of label relative to top-left corner of bounding box. For example: 

      // Absolute pixel values
      position: [10, 10],
      // Relative percentage
      position: ['50%', '50%']
* 'top'
* 'left'
* 'right'
* 'bottom'
* 'inside'
* 'insideLeft'
* 'insideRight'
* 'insideTop'
* 'insideBottom'
* 'insideTopLeft'
* 'insideBottomLeft'
* 'insideTopRight'
* 'insideBottomRight'

See: [label position][0].

[0]: https://echarts.apache.org/examples/en/view.html?c=doc-example/label-position

label.distance.desc:
Distance to the host graphic element. It is valid only when position is string value (like 'top'、'insideRight'). See: [label position][0].

[0]: https://echarts.apache.org/examples/en/editor.html?c=doc-example/label-position

label.rotate.desc:
Rotate label, from -90 degree to 90, positive value represents rotate anti-clockwise. See: [label rotation][0].

[0]: https://echarts.apache.org/examples/en/editor.html?c=bar-label-rotation

label.offset.desc: Whether to move text slightly. For example: [30, 40] means move 30 horizontally and move 40 vertically.

label.color.desc: text color. If set as 'inherit', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

label.borderColor.desc: Border color of the text fragment. If set as 'inherit', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

label.borderWidth.desc: Border width of the text fragment.

label.borderType.desc:
the text fragment border type. Possible values are: 

* 'solid'
* 'dashed'
* 'dotted'

Since v5.0.0, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the [dash array][0] of the line. With borderDashOffset , we can make the line style more flexible. For example： 

    {
    
    borderType: [5, 10],
    
    borderDashOffset: 5
    }
    



[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray

label.borderDashOffset.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To set the line dash offset. With borderType , we can make the line style more flexible. Refer to MDN [lineDashOffset][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineDashOffset

label.borderRadius.desc: Border radius of the text fragment.

label.padding.desc:
Padding of the text fragment, for example: 

* padding: [3, 4, 5, 6]: represents padding of [top, right, bottom, left].
* padding: 4: represents padding: [4, 4, 4, 4].
* padding: [3, 4]: represents padding: [3, 4, 3, 4].

Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding.

label.shadowColor.desc: Shadow color of the text block.

label.shadowBlur.desc: Show blur of the text block.

label.shadowOffsetX.desc: Shadow X offset of the text block.

label.shadowOffsetY.desc: Shadow Y offset of the text block.

label.textBorderColor.desc: Storke color of the text. If set as 'inherit', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

label.textBorderWidth.desc: Storke line width of the text.

label.textBorderType.desc:
Stroke line type of the text. Possible values are: 

* 'solid'
* 'dashed'
* 'dotted'

Since v5.0.0, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the [dash array][0] of the line. With textBorderDashOffset , we can make the line style more flexible. For example： 

    {
    
    textBorderType: [5, 10],
    
    textBorderDashOffset: 5
    }
    



[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray

label.textBorderDashOffset.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To set the line dash offset. With textBorderType , we can make the line style more flexible. Refer to MDN [lineDashOffset][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineDashOffset

label.textShadowColor.desc: Shadow color of the text itself.

label.textShadowBlur.desc: Shadow blue of the text itself.

label.textShadowOffsetX.desc: Shadow X offset of the text itself.

label.textShadowOffsetY.desc: Shadow Y offset of the text itself.

label.overflow.desc:
Determine how to display the text when it's overflow. Available when width is set. 

* 'truncate' Truncate the text and trailing with ellipsis.
* 'break' Break by word
* 'breakAll' Break by character.

label.ellipsis.desc: Ellipsis to be displayed when overflow is set to truncate.

label.lineOverflow.desc:
Determine how to display the text when it's overflow on height. 

* 'truncate' Truncate the overflow lines.

label.rich.<style_name>.shadowOffsetY.desc: Shadow Y offset of the text block.

label.rich.<style_name>.width.desc: Width of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. In most cases, there is no need to specify it. You may want to use it in some cases like make simple table or using background image (see backgroundColor). Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding. width can also be percent string, like '100%', which represents the percent of contentWidth (that is, the width without padding) of its container box. It is based on contentWidth because that each text fragment is layout based on the content box, where it makes no sense that calculating width based on outerWith in prectice. Notice, width and height only work when rich specified.

label.rich.<style_name>.height.desc: Height of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. You may want to use it in some cases like using background image (see backgroundColor). Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding. Notice, width and height only work when rich specified.

labelLayout.hideOverlap.desc: If hide the overlapped labels. The following example shows how to hide the overlapped labels in graph automatically when zooming. 暂时无法显示

labelLayout.moveOverlap.desc:
If move the overlapped labels to avoid overlapping. Currently supported configurations: 

* 'shiftX' Place the labels on horizontal direction sequencely, used when aligned horizontally.
* 'shiftY' Place the labels on vertial direction sequencely, used when aligned vertically.

The following example shows how to use moverOverlap: 'shiftY' to place the labels aligned vertically. 暂时无法显示

labelLayout.x.desc: The x position of the label. Support absolute pixel values ​​or relative values ​​such as '20%'.

labelLayout.y.desc: The y position of the label. Support absolute pixel values ​​or relative values ​​such as '20%'.

labelLayout.dx.desc: The pixel offset of the label in the x direction. Can be used with x.

labelLayout.dy.desc: The pixel offset of the label in the y direction. Can be used with y

labelLayout.width.desc: The width of displayed label. Can be used with overflow to constraint the label in a fixed width

labelLayout.height.desc: The height of displayed label. Can be used with lineOverflow to constraint the label in a fixed height.

labelLayout.align.desc: The horizontal alignment of the label. Can be 'left', 'center', 'right'.

labelLayout.verticalAlign.desc: The vertical alignment of the label. Can be 'top', 'middle', 'bottom'.

labelLayout.fontSize.desc: The text size of the label.

labelLayout.draggable.desc: Whether to allow the user to adjust the position by dragging.

labelLayout.labelLinePoints.desc:
The array of the three points of the label guide line. The format is: 

    [[x, y], [x, y], [x, y]]
    

It is often used in pie charts to fine-tune the guide line that has been calculated. Usually not recommended to set it in other situations.

itemStyle.color.desc:
color. 

> Supports setting as solid color using > rgb(255,255,255)> , > rgba(255,255,255,1)> , > #fff> , etc. Also supports setting as gradient color and pattern fill, see [> option.color][0]>  for details 

[0]: #color

itemStyle.borderColor.desc: border color, whose format is similar to that of color.

itemStyle.borderWidth.desc: border width. No border when it is set to be 0. border width. No border when it is set to be 0.

itemStyle.borderType.desc:
border type. Possible values are: 

* 'solid'
* 'dashed'
* 'dotted'

Since v5.0.0, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the [dash array][0] of the line. With borderDashOffset , we can make the line style more flexible. For example： 

    {
    
    borderType: [5, 10],
    
    borderDashOffset: 5
    }
    



[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray

itemStyle.borderDashOffset.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To set the line dash offset. With borderType , we can make the line style more flexible. Refer to MDN [lineDashOffset][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineDashOffset

itemStyle.borderCap.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To specify how to draw the end points of the line. Possible values are: 

* 'butt': The ends of lines are squared off at the endpoints.
* 'round': The ends of lines are rounded.
* 'square': The ends of lines are squared off by adding a box with an equal width and half the height of the line's thickness.

Default value is 'butt'. Refer to MDN [lineCap][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineCap

itemStyle.borderJoin.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To determine the shape used to join two line segments where they meet. Possible values are: 

* 'bevel': Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
* 'round': Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.
* 'miter': Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the borderMiterLimit property.

Default value is 'bevel'. Refer to MDN [lineJoin][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineJoin

itemStyle.borderMiterLimit.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To set the miter limit ratio. Only works when borderJoin is set as miter. Default value is 10. Negative、0、Infinity and NaN values are ignored. Refer to MDN [miterLimit][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/miterLimit

itemStyle.shadowColor.desc: Shadow color. Support same format as color.

itemStyle.shadowOffsetX.desc: Offset distance on the horizontal direction of shadow.

itemStyle.shadowOffsetY.desc: Offset distance on the vertical direction of shadow.

itemStyle.opacity.desc: Opacity of the component. Supports value from 0 to 1, and the component will not be drawn when set to 0.

emphasis.focus.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 When the data is highlighted, whether to fade out of other data to focus the highlighted. The following configurations are supported: 

* 'none' Do not fade out other data, it's by default.
* 'self' Only focus (not fade out) the element of the currently highlighted data.

* 'series' Focus on all elements of the series which the currently highlighted data belongs to.

**Example:**    emphasis: {
        focus: 'series',
        blurScope: 'coordinateSystem'
    }
    

暂时无法显示

emphasis.blurScope.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 The range of fade out when focus is enabled. Support the following configurations 

* 'coordinateSystem'
* 'series'
* 'global'

You may want to use it in some cases like make simple table or using background image (see backgroundColor). Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding. width can also be percent string, like '100%', which represents the percent of contentWidth (that is, the width without padding) of its container box. It is based on contentWidth because that each text fragment is layout based on the content box, where it makes no sense that calculating width based on outerWith in prectice. Notice, width and height only work when rich specified.

emphasis.label.rich.<style_name>.height.desc: Height of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. You may want to use it in some cases like using background image (see backgroundColor). universalTransition.desc: Configuration related to universal transition animation. Universal Transition provides the ability to morph between any series. With this feature enabled, each time setOption, transitions between series with the same id will be automatically associated with each other. One-to-many or many-to-one animations such as drill-down, aggregation, etc. can also be achieved by specifying groups of data such as encode.itemGroupId or dataGroupId. This can be enabled directly by configuring universalTransition: true in the series. It is also possible to provide an object for more detailed configuration.

universalTransition.enabled.desc: Wheather to enable the universal transition animation.

universalTransition.seriesKey.desc:
The seriesKey determines how the series to be animated is associated, it defaults to the id of the series when not configured. Usually this is configured as a string, and transitions between series with the same seriesKey will be applied. It can also be configured as an array like the following. 

    seriesKey: ['male', 'female']
    

Configuring to an array means that all series specified by the array item will be merged into the current series when animating. For example, this configuration means that series with id or seriesKey of 'male' and 'female' will be merged into the current series.

universalTransition.divideShape.desc:
divideShape determines how the elements in the current series will split into multiple elements in a one-to-many or many-to-one animation. Currently supports 

* 'split' Split the shape into multiple shapes.
* 'clone' Get multiple clones from the current element.

For better results, different series will have different configurations by default, for example, [scatter][0] with smaller and more complex element uses 'clone' by default, while more regular ones like bar charts default to 'split'. You can set this to the desired splitting strategy according to the needs of your own scenario.

[0]: #series-scatter

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineDashOffset

blur.itemStyle.borderCap.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To specify how to draw the end points of the line. Possible values are: 

* 'butt': The ends of lines are squared off at the endpoints.
* 'round': The ends of lines are rounded.
* 'square': The ends of lines are squared off by adding a box with an equal width and half the height of the line's thickness.

Default value is 'butt'. Refer to MDN [lineCap][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineCap

blur.itemStyle.borderJoin.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To determine the shape used to join two line segments where they meet. Possible values are: 

* 'bevel': Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
* 'round': Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.
* 'miter': Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the borderMiterLimit property.

Default value is 'bevel'. Refer to MDN [lineJoin][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineJoin

blur.itemStyle.borderMiterLimit.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To set the miter limit ratio. Only works when borderJoin is set as miter. Default value is 10. Negative、0、Infinity and NaN values are ignored. Refer to MDN [miterLimit][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/miterLimit

select.label.rich.<style_name>.textBorde.desc: Storke color of the text. If set as 'inherit', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.
Storke line width of the text.

Stroke line type of the text. Possible values are: 

* 'solid'
* 'dashed'
* 'dotted'

Since v5.0.0, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the [dash array][0] of the line. With textBorderDashOffset , we can make the line style more flexible. For example： 

    {
    
    textBorderType: [5, 10],
    
    textBorderDashOffset: 5
    }
    



[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray

select.label.rich.<style_name>.textShado.desc: Shadow color of the text itself.
Shadow blue of the text itself.
Shadow X offset of the text itself.
Shadow Y offset of the text itself.

selectedMode.desc: >  Since > v5.0.0 Selected mode. It is enabled by default, and you may set it to be false to disabled it. Besides, it can be set to 'single' or 'multiple', for single selection and multiple selections.

seriesLayoutBy.desc:
When [dataset][0] is used, seriesLayoutBy specifies whether the column or the row of dataset is mapped to the series, namely, the series is "layout" on columns or rows. Optional values: 

* 'column': by default, the columns of dataset are mapped the series. In this case, each column represents a dimension.
* 'row'：the rows of dataset are mapped to the series. In this case, each row represents a dimension.

Check this [example][1].

[0]: #dataset
[1]: https://echarts.apache.org/examples/en/editor.html?c=dataset-series-layout-by

datasetIndex.desc:
If [series.data][0] is not specified, and [dataset][1] exists, the series will use dataset. datasetIndex specifies which dataset will be used.

[0]: #series.data
[1]: #dataset

dataGroupId.desc:
A groupID common to all data in the series. the groupID will be used to classify the data and determine how merge and split animations are performed in the universal transition animation. If you are using the [dataset][0] component to represent the data, it is recommended to use encode.itemGroupID to specify which dimension is encoded as the groupID.

[0]: #dataset

data.groupId.desc: The groupID of this data item. groupID will be used to classify the data.

data.label.desc:
It is valid with [coordinateSystem][0] of 'cartesian2d' value.

[0]: #series-heatmap.coordinateSystem

data.label.position.desc:
Label position. **Followings are the options:*** [x, y] Use relative percentage, or absolute pixel values to represent position of label relative to top-left corner of bounding box. For example: 

      // Absolute pixel values
      position: [10, 10],
      // Relative percentage
      position: ['50%', '50%']
* 'top'
* 'left'
* 'right'
* 'bottom'
* 'inside'
* 'insideLeft'
* 'insideRight'
* 'insideTop'
* 'insideBottom'
* 'insideTopLeft'
* 'insideBottomLeft'
* 'insideTopRight'
* 'insideBottomRight'

See: [label position][0].

[0]: https://echarts.apache.org/examples/en/view.html?c=doc-example/label-position

data.label.distance.desc:
Distance to the host graphic element. It is valid only when position is string value (like 'top'、'insideRight'). See: [label position][0].

[0]: https://echarts.apache.org/examples/en/editor.html?c=doc-example/label-position

data.label.rotate.desc:
Rotate label, from -90 degree to 90, positive value represents rotate anti-clockwise. See: [label rotation][0].

[0]: https://echarts.apache.org/examples/en/editor.html?c=bar-label-rotation

data.label.offset.desc: Whether to move text slightly. For example: [30, 40] means move 30 horizontally and move 40 vertically.

data.label.color.desc: text color. If set as 'inherit', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

data.label.borderColor.desc: Border color of the text fragment. If set as 'inherit', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

data.label.borderWidth.desc: Border width of the text fragment.

data.label.borderType.desc:
the text fragment border type. Possible values are: 

* 'solid'
* 'dashed'
* 'dotted'

Since v5.0.0, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the [dash array][0] of the line. With borderDashOffset , we can make the line style more flexible. For example： 

    {
    
    borderType: [5, 10],
    
    borderDashOffset: 5
    }

data.label.borderDashOffset.desc:

data.label.borderRadius.desc: Border radius of the text fragment.

data.label.padding.desc:
Padding of the text fragment, for example: 

* padding: [3, 4, 5, 6]: represents padding of [top, right, bottom, left].
* padding: 4: represents padding: [4, 4, 4, 4].
* padding: [3, 4]: represents padding: [3, 4, 3, 4].

Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding.

data.label.overflow.desc:
Determine how to display the text when it's overflow. Available when width is set. 

* 'truncate' Truncate the text and trailing with ellipsis.
* 'break' Break by word
* 'breakAll' Break by character.

data.label.ellipsis.desc: Ellipsis to be displayed when overflow is set to truncate.

data.label.lineOverflow.desc:
Determine how to display the text when it's overflow on height. 

* 'truncate' Truncate the overflow lines.

data.label.rich.<style_name>.width.desc: Width of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. In most cases, there is no need to specify it. You may want to use it in some cases like make simple table or using background image (see backgroundColor). Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding. width can also be percent string, like '100%', which represents the percent of contentWidth (that is, the width without padding) of its container box. It is based on contentWidth because that each text fragment is layout based on the content box, where it makes no sense that calculating width based on outerWith in prectice. Notice, width and height only work when rich specified.

color.

[0]: #color

data.itemStyle.borderWidth.desc: border width. No border when it is set to be 0. border width. No border when it is set to be 0.

Since v5.0.0, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the [dash array][0] of the line. With borderDashOffset , we can make the line style more flexible. For example：

>  Since > v5.0.0 To set the line dash offset. With borderType , we can make the line style more flexible. Refer to MDN [lineDashOffset][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineDashOffset

data.itemStyle.borderCap.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To specify how to draw the end points of the line. Possible values are: 

* 'butt': The ends of lines are squared off at the endpoints.
* 'round': The ends of lines are rounded.
* 'square': The ends of lines are squared off by adding a box with an equal width and half the height of the line's thickness.

Default value is 'butt'. Refer to MDN [lineCap][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineCap

data.itemStyle.borderJoin.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To determine the shape used to join two line segments where they meet. Possible values are: 

* 'bevel': Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
* 'round': Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.
* 'miter': Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the borderMiterLimit property.

Default value is 'bevel'. Refer to MDN [lineJoin][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineJoin

data.itemStyle.borderMiterLimit.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To set the miter limit ratio. Only works when borderJoin is set as miter. Default value is 10. Negative、0、Infinity and NaN values are ignored. Refer to MDN [miterLimit][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/miterLimit

data.itemStyle.shadowOffsetY.desc: Offset distance on the vertical direction of shadow.

data.itemStyle.opacity.desc: Opacity of the component. Supports value from 0 to 1, and the component will not be drawn when set to 0.

markPoint.symbol.desc:
Symbol of . Icon types provided by ECharts includes 'circle', 'rect', 'roundRect', 'triangle', 'diamond', 'pin', 'arrow', 'none' It can be set to an image with 'image://url' , in which URL is the link to an image, or dataURI of an image. An image URL example: 

    'image://http://xxx.xxx.xxx/a/b.png'
    

A dataURI example: 

    'image://data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhEAAQAMQAAORHHOVSKudfOulrSOp3WOyDZu6QdvCchPGolfO0o/XBs/fNwfjZ0frl3/zy7////wAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAACH5BAkAABAALAAAAAAQABAAAAVVICSOZGlCQAosJ6mu7fiyZeKqNKToQGDsM8hBADgUXoGAiqhSvp5QAnQKGIgUhwFUYLCVDFCrKUE1lBavAViFIDlTImbKC5Gm2hB0SlBCBMQiB0UjIQA7'
    

Icons can be set to arbitrary vector path via 'path://' in ECharts. As compared with a raster image, vector paths prevent jagging and blurring when scaled, and have better control over changing colors. The size of the vector icon will be adapted automatically. Refer to [SVG PathData][0] for more information about the format of the path. You may export vector paths from tools like Adobe For example: 

    'path://M30.9,53.2C16.8,53.2,5.3,41.7,5.3,27.6S16.8,2,30.9,2C45,2,56.4,13.5,56.4,27.6S45,53.2,30.9,53.2z M30.9,3.5C17.6,3.5,6.8,14.4,6.8,27.6c0,13.3,10.8,24.1,24.101,24.1C44.2,51.7,55,40.9,55,27.6C54.9,14.4,44.1,3.5,30.9,3.5z M36.9,35.8c0,0.601-0.4,1-0.9,1h-1.3c-0.5,0-0.9-0.399-0.9-1V19.5c0-0.6,0.4-1,0.9-1H36c0.5,0,0.9,0.4,0.9,1V35.8z M27.8,35.8 c0,0.601-0.4,1-0.9,1h-1.3c-0.5,0-0.9-0.399-0.9-1V19.5c0-0.6,0.4-1,0.9-1H27c0.5,0,0.9,0.4,0.9,1L27.8,35.8L27.8,35.8z'
    

If symbols needs to be different, you can set with callback function in the following format: 

    (value: Array|number, params: Object) => string
    

The first parameter value is the value in [data][1], and the second parameter params is the rest parameters of data item.

[0]: http://www.w3.org/TR/SVG/paths.html#PathData
[1]: #series-heatmap.data

markPoint.symbolSize.desc:
symbol size. It can be set to single numbers like 10, or use an array to represent width and height. For example, [20, 10] means symbol width is 20, and height is10. If size of symbols needs to be different, you can set with callback function in the following format: 

    (value: Array|number, params: Object) => number|Array
    

The first parameter value is the value in [data][0], and the second parameter params is the rest parameters of data item.

[0]: #series-heatmap.data

markPoint.symbolRotate.desc:
Rotate degree of symbol. The negative value represents clockwise. Note that when symbol is set to be 'arrow' in markLine, symbolRotate value will be ignored, and compulsively use tangent angle. If rotation of symbols needs to be different, you can set with callback function in the following format: 

    (value: Array|number, params: Object) => number
    

The first parameter value is the value in [data][0], and the second parameter params is the rest parameters of data item. 

> Callback is supported since 4.8.0 . 

[0]: #series-heatmap.data

markPoint.symbolKeepAspect.desc: Whether to keep aspect for symbols in the form of path://.

markPoint.symbolOffset.desc: Offset of symbol relative to original position. By default, symbol will be put in the center position of data. But if symbol is from user-defined vector path or image, you may not expect symbol to be in center. In this case, you may use this attribute to set offset to default position. It can be in absolute pixel value, or in relative percentage value. For example, [0, '-50%'] means to move upside side position of symbol height. It can be used to make the arrow in the bottom to be at data position when symbol is pin.

markPoint.silent.desc: Whether to ignore mouse events. Default value is false, for triggering and responding to mouse events.

markPoint.label.position.desc:
Label position. **Followings are the options:*** [x, y] Use relative percentage, or absolute pixel values to represent position of label relative to top-left corner of bounding box. For example: 

      // Absolute pixel values
      position: [10, 10],
      // Relative percentage
      position: ['50%', '50%']

markPoint.label.rich.<style_name>.width.desc: Width of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. In most cases, there is no need to specify it. You may want to use it in some cases like make simple table or using background image (see backgroundColor). Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding. width can also be percent string, like '100%', which represents the percent of contentWidth (that is, the width without padding) of its container box. markPoint.itemStyle.borderCap.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To specify how to draw the end points of the line. Possible values are: 

* 'butt': The ends of lines are squared off at the endpoints.
* 'round': The ends of lines are rounded.
* 'square': The ends of lines are squared off by adding a box with an equal width and half the height of the line's thickness.

Default value is 'butt'. Refer to MDN [lineCap][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineCap

markPoint.itemStyle.borderJoin.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To determine the shape used to join two line segments where they meet. Possible values are: 

* 'bevel': Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
* 'round': Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.
* 'miter': Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the borderMiterLimit property.

Default value is 'bevel'. Refer to MDN [lineJoin][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineJoin

markPoint.itemStyle.borderMiterLimit.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To set the miter limit ratio. Only works when borderJoin is set as miter. Default value is 10. Negative、0、Infinity and NaN values are ignored. Refer to MDN [miterLimit][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/miterLimit

* 'butt': The ends of lines are squared off at the endpoints.
* 'round': The ends of lines are rounded.
* 'square': The ends of lines are squared off by adding a box with an equal width and half the height of the line's thickness.

Default value is 'butt'. Refer to MDN [lineCap][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineCap

markPoint.emphasis.itemStyle.borderJoin.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To determine the shape used to join two line segments where they meet. Possible values are: 

* 'bevel': Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
* 'round': Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.
* 'miter': Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the borderMiterLimit property.

Default value is 'bevel'. Refer to MDN [lineJoin][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineJoin

markPoint.emphasis.itemStyle.borderMiter.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To set the miter limit ratio. Only works when borderJoin is set as miter. Default value is 10. Negative、0、Infinity and NaN values are ignored. Refer to MDN [miterLimit][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/miterLimit

markPoint.emphasis.itemStyle.shadowColor.desc: Shadow color. Support same format as color.

markPoint.emphasis.itemStyle.shadowOffse.desc: Offset distance on the horizontal direction of shadow.
Offset distance on the vertical direction of shadow.

markPoint.emphasis.itemStyle.opacity.desc: Opacity of the component. Supports value from 0 to 1, and the component will not be drawn when set to 0.

markPoint.blur.desc: >  Since > v5.0.0 Configurations of blur state. Whether to blur follows the series.

markPoint.blur.label.position.desc:
Label position. **Followings are the options:*** [x, y] Use relative percentage, or absolute pixel values to represent position of label relative to top-left corner of bounding box. For example: 

      // Absolute pixel values
      position: [10, 10],
      // Relative percentage
      position: ['50%', '50%']
* 'top'
* 'left'
* 'right'
* 'bottom'
* 'inside'
* 'insideLeft'
* 'insideRight'
* 'insideTop'
* 'insideBottom'
* 'insideTopLeft'
* 'insideBottomLeft'
* 'insideTopRight'
* 'insideBottomRight'

See: [label position][0].

[0]: https://echarts.apache.org/examples/en/view.html?c=doc-example/label-position

markPoint.blur.label.distance.desc:
Distance to the host graphic element. It is valid only when position is string value (like 'top'、'insideRight'). See: [label position][0].

[0]: https://echarts.apache.org/examples/en/editor.html?c=doc-example/label-position

markPoint.blur.label.rotate.desc:
Rotate label, from -90 degree to 90, positive value represents rotate anti-clockwise. See: [label rotation][0].

[0]: https://echarts.apache.org/examples/en/editor.html?c=bar-label-rotation

markPoint.blur.label.offset.desc: Whether to move text slightly. For example: [30, 40] means move 30 horizontally and move 40 vertically.

markPoint.blur.label.color.desc: text color. If set as 'inherit', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

markPoint.blur.label.borderColor.desc: Border color of the text fragment. If set as 'inherit', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

markPoint.blur.label.borderWidth.desc: Border width of the text fragment.

markPoint.blur.label.borderType.desc:
the text fragment border type. Possible values are: 

* 'solid'
* 'dashed'
* 'dotted'

Since v5.0.0, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the [dash array][0] of the line. With borderDashOffset , we can make the line style more flexible. For example： 

    {
    
    borderType: [5, 10],
    
    borderDashOffset: 5
    }
    



[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray

markPoint.blur.label.borderDashOffset.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To set the line dash offset. With borderType , we can make the line style more flexible. Refer to MDN [lineDashOffset][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineDashOffset

markPoint.blur.label.borderRadius.desc: Border radius of the text fragment.

markPoint.blur.label.padding.desc:
Padding of the text fragment, for example: 

* padding: [3, 4, 5, 6]: represents padding of [top, right, bottom, left].
* padding: 4: represents padding: [4, 4, 4, 4].
* padding: [3, 4]: represents padding: [3, 4, 3, 4].

Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding.

markPoint.blur.label.overflow.desc:
Determine how to display the text when it's overflow. Available when width is set. 

* 'truncate' Truncate the text and trailing with ellipsis.
* 'break' Break by word
* 'breakAll' Break by character.

markPoint.blur.label.ellipsis.desc: Ellipsis to be displayed when overflow is set to truncate.

markPoint.blur.label.lineOverflow.desc:
Determine how to display the text when it's overflow on height. 

* 'truncate' Truncate the overflow lines.

markPoint.blur.label.rich.<style_name>.s.desc: Shadow color of the text block.

markPoint.blur.label.rich.<style_name>.w.desc: Width of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. In most cases, there is no need to specify it. You may want to use it in some cases like make simple table or using background image (see backgroundColor). Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding. width can also be percent string, like '100%', which represents the percent of contentWidth (that is, the width without padding) of its container box. It is based on contentWidth because that each text fragment is layout based on the content box, where it makes no sense that calculating width based on outerWith in prectice. Notice, width and height only work when rich specified.

markPoint.blur.label.rich.<style_name>.h.desc: Height of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. You may want to use it in some cases like using background image (see backgroundColor). Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding. Notice, width and height only work when rich specified.

markPoint.data.desc:
Data array for mark points, each of which is an object. Here are some ways to assign mark point position. 

1. Assign coordinate according to container with [x][0], [y][1] attribute, in which pixel values and percentage are supported.

When multiple attributes exist, priority is as the above order. **For example:**    data: [
    
        {
            name: 'screen coordinate',
            x: 100,
            y: 100
        }
    ]
    



[0]: #series-heatmap.markPoint.data.x
[1]: #series-heatmap.markPoint.data.y

markPoint.data.x.desc: X position according to container, in pixel.

markPoint.data.y.desc: Y position according to container, in pixel.

markPoint.data.value.desc: Label value, which can be ignored.

markPoint.data.symbol.desc:
Symbol of . Icon types provided by ECharts includes 'circle', 'rect', 'roundRect', 'triangle', 'diamond', 'pin', 'arrow', 'none' It can be set to an image with 'image://url' , in which URL is the link to an image, or dataURI of an image. An image URL example: 

    'image://http://xxx.xxx.xxx/a/b.png'
    

A dataURI example: 

    'image://data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhEAAQAMQAAORHHOVSKudfOulrSOp3WOyDZu6QdvCchPGolfO0o/XBs/fNwfjZ0frl3/zy7////wAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAACH5BAkAABAALAAAAAAQABAAAAVVICSOZGlCQAosJ6mu7fiyZeKqNKToQGDsM8hBADgUXoGAiqhSvp5QAnQKGIgUhwFUYLCVDFCrKUE1lBavAViFIDlTImbKC5Gm2hB0SlBCBMQiB0UjIQA7'
    

Icons can be set to arbitrary vector path via 'path://' in ECharts. As compared with a raster image, vector paths prevent jagging and blurring when scaled, and have better control over changing colors. The size of the vector icon will be adapted automatically. Refer to [SVG PathData][0] for more information about the format of the path. You may export vector paths from tools like Adobe For example: 

    'path://M30.9,53.2C16.8,53.2,5.3,41.7,5.3,27.6S16.8,2,30.9,2C45,2,56.4,13.5,56.4,27.6S45,53.2,30.9,53.2z M30.9,3.5C17.6,3.5,6.8,14.4,6.8,27.6c0,13.3,10.8,24.1,24.101,24.1C44.2,51.7,55,40.9,55,27.6C54.9,14.4,44.1,3.5,30.9,3.5z M36.9,35.8c0,0.601-0.4,1-0.9,1h-1.3c-0.5,0-0.9-0.399-0.9-1V19.5c0-0.6,0.4-1,0.9-1H36c0.5,0,0.9,0.4,0.9,1V35.8z M27.8,35.8 c0,0.601-0.4,1-0.9,1h-1.3c-0.5,0-0.9-0.399-0.9-1V19.5c0-0.6,0.4-1,0.9-1H27c0.5,0,0.9,0.4,0.9,1L27.8,35.8L27.8,35.8z'
    

[0]: http://www.w3.org/TR/SVG/paths.html#PathData

markPoint.data.symbolSize.desc: symbol size. It can be set to single numbers like 10, or use an array to represent width and height. For example, [20, 10] means symbol width is 20, and height is10.

markPoint.data.symbolRotate.desc: Rotate degree of symbol. The negative value represents clockwise. Note that when symbol is set to be 'arrow' in markLine, symbolRotate value will be ignored, and compulsively use tangent angle.

markPoint.data.symbolKeepAspect.desc: Whether to keep aspect for symbols in the form of path://.

markPoint.data.symbolOffset.desc: Offset of symbol relative to original position. By default, symbol will be put in the center position of data. But if symbol is from user-defined vector path or image, you may not expect symbol to be in center. In this case, you may use this attribute to set offset to default position. It can be in absolute pixel value, or in relative percentage value. For example, [0, '-50%'] means to move upside side position of symbol height. It can be used to make the arrow in the bottom to be at data position when symbol is pin.

markPoint.data.label.rich.<style_name>.w.desc: Width of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. In most cases, there is no need to specify it. You may want to use it in some cases like make simple table or using background image (see backgroundColor). Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding. width can also be percent string, like '100%', which represents the percent of contentWidth (that is, the width without padding) of its container box. It is based on contentWidth because that each text fragment is layout based on the content box, where it makes no sense that calculating width based on outerWith in prectice. Notice, width and height only work when rich specified.

markPoint.data.label.rich.<style_name>.h.desc: Height of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. >  Since > v5.0.0 To specify how to draw the end points of the line. Possible values are: 

* 'butt': The ends of lines are squared off at the endpoints.
* 'round': The ends of lines are rounded.
* 'square': The ends of lines are squared off by adding a box with an equal width and half the height of the line's thickness.

Default value is 'butt'. Refer to MDN [lineCap][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineCap

>  Since > v5.0.0 To determine the shape used to join two line segments where they meet. Possible values are: 

* 'bevel': Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
* 'round': Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.
* 'miter': Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the borderMiterLimit property.

Default value is 'bevel'. Refer to MDN [lineJoin][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineJoin

>  Since > v5.0.0 To set the miter limit ratio. Only works when borderJoin is set as miter. Default value is 10. Negative、0、Infinity and NaN values are ignored. Refer to MDN [miterLimit][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/miterLimit

markLine.lineStyle.shadowColor.desc: Shadow color. Support same format as color.

markLine.lineStyle.shadowOffsetX.desc: Offset distance on the horizontal direction of shadow.

markLine.lineStyle.shadowOffsetY.desc: Offset distance on the vertical direction of shadow.

markLine.lineStyle.opacity.desc: Opacity of the component. Supports value from 0 to 1, and the component will not be drawn when set to 0.

markLine.lineStyle.curveness.desc: Edge curvature, which supports value from 0 to 1. The larger the value, the greater the curvature.

markLine.emphasis.label.position.desc:
Positions of labels can be: 

* 'start' starting point of the line.
* 'middle' middle point of the line.
* 'end' ending point of the line.

Since version 4.7.0, more label positions are supported: 'start', 'middle', 'end', 'insideStartTop', 'insideStartBottom', 'insideMiddleTop', 'insideMiddleBottom', 'insideEndTop', 'insideEndBottom'. 'insideMiddleBottom' is the same as 'middle'. Position is as the following chart. The distance between labels and mark lines can be set with [label.distance][0]. 暂时无法显示

[0]: #series-.markLine.label.distance

markLine.emphasis.label.distance.desc: The distance between labels and mark lines. If it's an array, then the first element is the horizontal distance, and the second element is the vertical distance. If it's a number, then the horizontal and vertical distances are the same.

markLine.emphasis.label.color.desc: text color. If set as 'inherit', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

markLine.emphasis.label.borderColor.desc: Border color of the text fragment. If set as 'inherit', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

markLine.emphasis.label.borderWidth.desc: Border width of the text fragment.

markLine.emphasis.label.borderType.desc:
the text fragment border type. Possible values are: 

* 'solid'
* 'dashed'
* 'dotted'

Since v5.0.0, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the [dash array][0] of the line. With borderDashOffset , we can make the line style more flexible. For example： 

    {
    
    borderType: [5, 10],
    
    borderDashOffset: 5
    }

markLine.emphasis.lineStyle.cap.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To specify how to draw the end points of the line. Possible values are: 

* 'butt': The ends of lines are squared off at the endpoints.
* 'round': The ends of lines are rounded.
* 'square': The ends of lines are squared off by adding a box with an equal width and half the height of the line's thickness.

Default value is 'butt'. Refer to MDN [lineCap][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineCap

markLine.emphasis.lineStyle.join.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To determine the shape used to join two line segments where they meet. Possible values are: 

* 'bevel': Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
* 'round': Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.
* 'miter': Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the miterLimit property.

Default value is 'bevel'. Refer to MDN [lineJoin][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineJoin

markLine.emphasis.lineStyle.miterLimit.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To set the miter limit ratio. Only works when join is set as miter. Default value is 10. Negative、0、Infinity and NaN values are ignored. Refer to MDN [miterLimit][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/miterLimit

markLine.data.0.name.desc: Name of the marker, which will display as a label.

markLine.data.0.x.desc: X position according to container, in pixel.

markLine.data.0.y.desc: Y position according to container, in pixel.

markLine.data.0.value.desc: Label value, which can be ignored.

markLine.data.0.symbol.desc:
Symbol of starting point. Icon types provided by ECharts includes 'circle', 'rect', 'roundRect', 'triangle', 'diamond', 'pin', 'arrow', 'none' It can be set to an image with 'image://url' , in which URL is the link to an image, or dataURI of an image. An image URL example: 

    'image://http://xxx.xxx.xxx/a/b.png'
    

A dataURI example: 

    'image://data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhEAAQAMQAAORHHOVSKudfOulrSOp3WOyDZu6QdvCchPGolfO0o/XBs/fNwfjZ0frl3/zy7////wAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAACH5BAkAABAALAAAAAAQABAAAAVVICSOZGlCQAosJ6mu7fiyZeKqNKToQGDsM8hBADgUXoGAiqhSvp5QAnQKGIgUhwFUYLCVDFCrKUE1lBavAViFIDlTImbKC5Gm2hB0SlBCBMQiB0UjIQA7'
    

Icons can be set to arbitrary vector path via 'path://' in ECharts. As compared with a raster image, vector paths prevent jagging and blurring when scaled, and have better control over changing colors. The size of the vector icon will be adapted automatically. Refer to [SVG PathData][0] for more information about the format of the path. You may export vector paths from tools like Adobe For example: 

    'path://M30.9,53.2C16.8,53.2,5.3,41.7,5.3,27.6S16.8,2,30.9,2C45,2,56.4,13.5,56.4,27.6S45,53.2,30.9,53.2z M30.9,3.5C17.6,3.5,6.8,14.4,6.8,27.6c0,13.3,10.8,24.1,24.101,24.1C44.2,51.7,55,40.9,55,27.6C54.9,14.4,44.1,3.5,30.9,3.5z M36.9,35.8c0,0.601-0.4,1-0.9,1h-1.3c-0.5,0-0.9-0.399-0.9-1V19.5c0-0.6,0.4-1,0.9-1H36c0.5,0,0.9,0.4,0.9,1V35.8z M27.8,35.8 c0,0.601-0.4,1-0.9,1h-1.3c-0.5,0-0.9-0.399-0.9-1V19.5c0-0.6,0.4-1,0.9-1H27c0.5,0,0.9,0.4,0.9,1L27.8,35.8L27.8,35.8z'
    

[0]: http://www.w3.org/TR/SVG/paths.html#PathData

markLine.data.0.symbolSize.desc: starting point symbol size. It can be set to single numbers like 10, or use an array to represent width and height. For example, [20, 10] means symbol width is 20, and height is10.

markLine.data.0.symbolRotate.desc: Rotate degree of starting point symbol. The negative value represents clockwise. Note that when symbol is set to be 'arrow' in markLine, symbolRotate value will be ignored, and compulsively use tangent angle.

markLine.data.0.symbolKeepAspect.desc: Whether to keep aspect for symbols in the form of path://.

markLine.data.0.symbolOffset.desc: Offset of starting point symbol relative to original position. By default, symbol will be put in the center position of data. But if symbol is from user-defined vector path or image, you may not expect symbol to be in center. In this case, you may use this attribute to set offset to default position. It can be in absolute pixel value, or in relative percentage value. For example, [0, '-50%'] means to move upside side position of symbol height. It can be used to make the arrow in the bottom to be at data position when symbol is pin.

markLine.data.0.lineStyle.desc: Line style of this data item, which will be merged with lineStyle of starting point and ending point.

markLine.data.0.lineStyle.color.desc:
Line color. 

> Supports setting as solid color using > rgb(255,255,255)> , > rgba(255,255,255,1)> , > #fff> , etc. Also supports setting as gradient color and pattern fill, see [> option.color][0]>  for details 

[0]: #color

markLine.data.0.lineStyle.type.desc:
line type. Possible values are: 

* 'solid'
* 'dashed'
* 'dotted'

Since v5.0.0, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the [dash array][0] of the line. With dashOffset , we can make the line style more flexible. For example： 

    {
    
    type: [5, 10],
    
    dashOffset: 5
    }
    



[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray

markLine.data.0.lineStyle.dashOffset.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To set the line dash offset. With type , we can make the line style more flexible. Refer to MDN [lineDashOffset][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineDashOffset

markLine.data.0.lineStyle.cap.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To specify how to draw the end points of the line. Possible values are: 

* 'butt': The ends of lines are squared off at the endpoints.
* 'round': The ends of lines are rounded.
* 'square': The ends of lines are squared off by adding a box with an equal width and half the height of the line's thickness.

Default value is 'butt'. Refer to MDN [lineCap][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineCap

markLine.data.0.lineStyle.join.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To determine the shape used to join two line segments where they meet. Possible values are: 

* 'bevel': Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
* 'round': Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.
* 'miter': Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the miterLimit property.

Default value is 'bevel'. Refer to MDN [lineJoin][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineJoin

markLine.data.0.lineStyle.miterLimit.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To set the miter limit ratio. Only works when join is set as miter. Default value is 10. Negative、0、Infinity and NaN values are ignored. Refer to MDN [miterLimit][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/miterLimit

markLine.data.0.lineStyle.shadowColor.desc: Shadow color. Support same format as color.

markLine.data.0.lineStyle.shadowOffsetX.desc: Offset distance on the horizontal direction of shadow.

markLine.data.0.lineStyle.shadowOffsetY.desc: Offset distance on the vertical direction of shadow.

markLine.data.0.lineStyle.opacity.desc: Opacity of the component. Supports value from 0 to 1, and the component will not be drawn when set to 0.

markLine.data.0.lineStyle.curveness.desc: Edge curvature, which supports value from 0 to 1. The larger the value, the greater the curvature.

markLine.data.0.label.desc: Label of this data item, which will be merged with label of starting point and ending point.

markLine.data.0.label.position.desc:
Positions of labels can be: 

* 'start' starting point of the line.
* 'middle' middle point of the line.
* 'end' ending point of the line.

Since version 4.7.0, more label positions are supported: 'start', 'middle', 'end', 'insideStartTop', 'insideStartBottom', 'insideMiddleTop', 'insideMiddleBottom', 'insideEndTop', 'insideEndBottom'. 'insideMiddleBottom' is the same as 'middle'. Position is as the following chart. The distance between labels and mark lines can be set with [label.distance][0]. 暂时无法显示

[0]: #series-.markLine.label.distance

markLine.data.0.label.distance.desc: The distance between labels and mark lines. If it's an array, then the first element is the horizontal distance, and the second element is the vertical distance. If it's a number, then the horizontal and vertical distances are the same.

markLine.data.0.label.color.desc: text color. If set as 'inherit', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

markLine.data.0.label.borderColor.desc: Border color of the text fragment. If set as 'inherit', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

markLine.data.0.label.borderWidth.desc: Border width of the text fragment.

markLine.data.0.label.borderType.desc:
the text fragment border type. Possible values are: 

* 'solid'
* 'dashed'
* 'dotted'

Since v5.0.0, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the [dash array][0] of the line. With borderDashOffset , we can make the line style more flexible. For example：

markLine.data.0.label.borderRadius.desc: Border radius of the text fragment.

markLine.data.0.label.padding.desc:
Padding of the text fragment, for example: 

* padding: [3, 4, 5, 6]: represents padding of [top, right, bottom, left].
* padding: 4: represents padding: [4, 4, 4, 4].
* padding: [3, 4]: represents padding: [3, 4, 3, 4].

Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding.

markLine.data.0.label.overflow.desc:
Determine how to display the text when it's overflow. Available when width is set. 

* 'truncate' Truncate the text and trailing with ellipsis.
* 'break' Break by word
* 'breakAll' Break by character.

markLine.data.0.label.ellipsis.desc: Ellipsis to be displayed when overflow is set to truncate.

markLine.data.0.label.lineOverflow.desc:
Determine how to display the text when it's overflow on height. 

* 'truncate' Truncate the overflow lines.

Positions of labels can be: 

* 'start' starting point of the line.
* 'middle' middle point of the line.
* 'end' ending point of the line.

Since version 4.7.0, more label positions are supported: 'start', 'middle', 'end', 'insideStartTop', 'insideStartBottom', 'insideMiddleTop', 'insideMiddleBottom', 'insideEndTop', 'insideEndBottom'. 'insideMiddleBottom' is the same as 'middle'. Position is as the following chart. The distance between labels and mark lines can be set with [label.distance][0]. 暂时无法显示

[0]: #series-.markLine.label.distance

markLine.data.0.blur.label.distance.desc: The distance between labels and mark lines. If it's an array, then the first element is the horizontal distance, and the second element is the vertical distance. If it's a number, then the horizontal and vertical distances are the same.

markLine.data.0.blur.label.color.desc: text color. If set as 'inherit', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

markLine.data.0.blur.label.borderColor.desc: Border color of the text fragment. If set as 'inherit', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

markLine.data.0.blur.label.borderWidth.desc: Border width of the text fragment.

markLine.data.0.blur.label.borderType.desc:
the text fragment border type. Possible values are: 

* 'solid'
* 'dashed'
* 'dotted'

Since v5.0.0, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the [dash array][0] of the line. With borderDashOffset , we can make the line style more flexible. For example： 

    {
    
    borderType: [5, 10],
    
    borderDashOffset: 5
    }
    



[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray

markLine.data.0.blur.label.borderDashOff.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To set the line dash offset. With borderType , we can make the line style more flexible. Refer to MDN [lineDashOffset][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineDashOffset

markLine.data.0.blur.label.borderRadius.desc: Border radius of the text fragment.

markLine.data.0.blur.label.padding.desc:
Padding of the text fragment, for example: 

* padding: [3, 4, 5, 6]: represents padding of [top, right, bottom, left].
* padding: 4: represents padding: [4, 4, 4, 4].
* padding: [3, 4]: represents padding: [3, 4, 3, 4].

Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding.

markLine.data.0.blur.label.shadowColor.desc: Shadow color of the text block.

markLine.data.0.blur.label.shadowBlur.desc: Show blur of the text block.

markLine.data.0.blur.label.shadowOffsetX.desc: Shadow X offset of the text block.

markLine.data.0.blur.label.shadowOffsetY.desc: Shadow Y offset of the text block.

markLine.data.0.blur.label.textBorderCol.desc: Storke color of the text. If set as 'inherit', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

markLine.data.0.blur.label.textBorderWid.desc: Storke line width of the text.

markLine.data.0.blur.label.overflow.desc:
Determine how to display the text when it's overflow. Available when width is set. 

* 'truncate' Truncate the text and trailing with ellipsis.
* 'break' Break by word
* 'breakAll' Break by character.

markLine.data.0.blur.label.ellipsis.desc: Ellipsis to be displayed when overflow is set to truncate.

markLine.data.0.blur.label.lineOverflow.desc:
Determine how to display the text when it's overflow on height. 

* 'truncate' Truncate the overflow lines.

Width of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. In most cases, there is no need to specify it. Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding. width can also be percent string, like '100%', which represents the percent of contentWidth (that is, the width without padding) of its container box. It is based on contentWidth because that each text fragment is layout based on the content box, where it makes no sense that calculating width based on outerWith in prectice. markLine.data.1.name.desc: Name of the marker, which will display as a label.

markLine.data.1.x.desc: X position according to container, in pixel.

markLine.data.1.y.desc: Y position according to container, in pixel.

markLine.data.1.value.desc: Label value, which can be ignored.

markLine.data.1.symbol.desc:
Symbol of ending point. Icon types provided by ECharts includes 'circle', 'rect', 'roundRect', 'triangle', 'diamond', 'pin', 'arrow', 'none' It can be set to an image with 'image://url' , in which URL is the link to an image, or dataURI of an image. An image URL example: 

    'image://http://xxx.xxx.xxx/a/b.png'
    

A dataURI example: 

    'image://data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhEAAQAMQAAORHHOVSKudfOulrSOp3WOyDZu6QdvCchPGolfO0o/XBs/fNwfjZ0frl3/zy7////wAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAACH5BAkAABAALAAAAAAQABAAAAVVICSOZGlCQAosJ6mu7fiyZeKqNKToQGDsM8hBADgUXoGAiqhSvp5QAnQKGIgUhwFUYLCVDFCrKUE1lBavAViFIDlTImbKC5Gm2hB0SlBCBMQiB0UjIQA7'
    

Icons can be set to arbitrary vector path via 'path://' in ECharts. As compared with a raster image, vector paths prevent jagging and blurring when scaled, and have better control over changing colors. The size of the vector icon will be adapted automatically. Refer to [SVG PathData][0] for more information about the format of the path. You may export vector paths from tools like Adobe For example: 

    'path://M30.9,53.2C16.8,53.2,5.3,41.7,5.3,27.6S16.8,2,30.9,2C45,2,56.4,13.5,56.4,27.6S45,53.2,30.9,53.2z M30.9,3.5C17.6,3.5,6.8,14.4,6.8,27.6c0,13.3,10.8,24.1,24.101,24.1C44.2,51.7,55,40.9,55,27.6C54.9,14.4,44.1,3.5,30.9,3.5z M36.9,35.8c0,0.601-0.4,1-0.9,1h-1.3c-0.5,0-0.9-0.399-0.9-1V19.5c0-0.6,0.4-1,0.9-1H36c0.5,0,0.9,0.4,0.9,1V35.8z M27.8,35.8 c0,0.601-0.4,1-0.9,1h-1.3c-0.5,0-0.9-0.399-0.9-1V19.5c0-0.6,0.4-1,0.9-1H27c0.5,0,0.9,0.4,0.9,1L27.8,35.8L27.8,35.8z'
    

[0]: http://www.w3.org/TR/SVG/paths.html#PathData

markLine.data.1.symbolSize.desc: ending point symbol size. It can be set to single numbers like 10, or use an array to represent width and height. For example, [20, 10] means symbol width is 20, and height is10.

markLine.data.1.symbolRotate.desc: Rotate degree of ending point symbol. The negative value represents clockwise. Note that when symbol is set to be 'arrow' in markLine, symbolRotate value will be ignored, and compulsively use tangent angle.

markLine.data.1.symbolKeepAspect.desc: Whether to keep aspect for symbols in the form of path://.

markLine.data.1.symbolOffset.desc: Offset of ending point symbol relative to original position. By default, symbol will be put in the center position of data. But if symbol is from user-defined vector path or image, you may not expect symbol to be in center. In this case, you may use this attribute to set offset to default position. It can be in absolute pixel value, or in relative percentage value. For example, [0, '-50%'] means to move upside side position of symbol height. It can be used to make the arrow in the bottom to be at data position when symbol is pin.

markLine.data.1.lineStyle.desc: Line style of this data item, which will be merged with lineStyle of starting point and ending point.

markLine.data.1.lineStyle.color.desc:
Line color. 

> Supports setting as solid color using > rgb(255,255,255)> , > rgba(255,255,255,1)> , > #fff> , etc. Also supports setting as gradient color and pattern fill, see [> option.color][0]>  for details 

[0]: #color

markLine.data.1.lineStyle.type.desc:
line type. Possible values are: 

* 'solid'
* 'dashed'
* 'dotted'

Since v5.0.0, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the [dash array][0] of the line. With dashOffset , we can make the line style more flexible. For example： 

    {
    
    type: [5, 10],
    
    dashOffset: 5
    }
    



[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray

markLine.data.1.lineStyle.dashOffset.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To set the line dash offset. With type , we can make the line style more flexible. Refer to MDN [lineDashOffset][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineDashOffset

markLine.data.1.lineStyle.cap.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To specify how to draw the end points of the line. Possible values are: 

* 'butt': The ends of lines are squared off at the endpoints.
* 'round': The ends of lines are rounded.
* 'square': The ends of lines are squared off by adding a box with an equal width and half the height of the line's thickness.

Default value is 'butt'. Refer to MDN [lineCap][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineCap

markLine.data.1.lineStyle.join.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To determine the shape used to join two line segments where they meet. Possible values are: 

* 'bevel': Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
* 'round': Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.
* 'miter': Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the miterLimit property.

Default value is 'bevel'. Refer to MDN [lineJoin][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineJoin

markLine.data.1.lineStyle.miterLimit.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To set the miter limit ratio. Only works when join is set as miter. Default value is 10. Negative、0、Infinity and NaN values are ignored. Refer to MDN [miterLimit][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/miterLimit

markLine.data.1.lineStyle.shadowColor.desc: Shadow color. Support same format as color.

markLine.data.1.lineStyle.shadowOffsetX.desc: Offset distance on the horizontal direction of shadow.

markLine.data.1.lineStyle.shadowOffsetY.desc: Offset distance on the vertical direction of shadow.

markLine.data.1.lineStyle.opacity.desc: Opacity of the component. Supports value from 0 to 1, and the component will not be drawn when set to 0.

markLine.data.1.lineStyle.curveness.desc: Edge curvature, which supports value from 0 to 1. The larger the value, the greater the curvature.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/miterLimit

markLine.data.1.emphasis.lineStyle.shado.desc: Shadow color. Support same format as color.
Offset distance on the horizontal direction of shadow.
Offset distance on the vertical direction of shadow.

markLine.data.1.emphasis.lineStyle.opaci.desc: Opacity of the component. Supports value from 0 to 1, and the component will not be drawn when set to 0.

markLine.data.1.emphasis.lineStyle.curve.desc: Edge curvature, which supports value from 0 to 1. The larger the value, the greater the curvature.

markLine.data.1.emphasis.label.position.desc:
Positions of labels can be: 

* 'start' starting point of the line.
* 'middle' middle point of the line.
* 'end' ending point of the line.

Since version 4.7.0, more label positions are supported: 'start', 'middle', 'end', 'insideStartTop', 'insideStartBottom', 'insideMiddleTop', 'insideMiddleBottom', 'insideEndTop', 'insideEndBottom'. 'insideMiddleBottom' is the same as 'middle'. Position is as the following chart. The distance between labels and mark lines can be set with [label.distance][0]. 暂时无法显示

[0]: #series-.markLine.label.distance

markLine.data.1.emphasis.label.distance.desc: The distance between labels and mark lines. If it's an array, then the first element is the horizontal distance, and the second element is the vertical distance. If it's a number, then the horizontal and vertical distances are the same.

markLine.data.1.emphasis.label.color.desc: text color. If set as 'inherit', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

markLine.data.1.emphasis.label.borderCol.desc: Border color of the text fragment. If set as 'inherit', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

markLine.data.1.emphasis.label.borderWid.desc: Border width of the text fragment.

markLine.data.1.emphasis.label.borderTyp.desc:
the text fragment border type. Possible values are: 

* 'solid'
* 'dashed'
* 'dotted'

Since v5.0.0, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the [dash array][0] of the line. With borderDashOffset , we can make the line style more flexible. For example： 

    {
    
    borderType: [5, 10],
    
    borderDashOffset: 5
    }
    



[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray

markLine.data.1.emphasis.label.borderDas.desc:

markLine.data.1.emphasis.label.padding.desc:
Padding of the text fragment, for example: 

* padding: [3, 4, 5, 6]: represents padding of [top, right, bottom, left].
* padding: 4: represents padding: [4, 4, 4, 4].
* padding: [3, 4]: represents padding: [3, 4, 3, 4].

Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding.

markLine.data.1.blur.lineStyle.dashOffse.desc:

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineDashOffset

markLine.data.1.blur.lineStyle.cap.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To specify how to draw the end points of the line. Possible values are: 

* 'butt': The ends of lines are squared off at the endpoints.
* 'round': The ends of lines are rounded.
* 'square': The ends of lines are squared off by adding a box with an equal width and half the height of the line's thickness.

Default value is 'butt'. Refer to MDN [lineCap][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineCap

markLine.data.1.blur.lineStyle.join.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To determine the shape used to join two line segments where they meet. Possible values are: 

* 'bevel': Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
* 'round': Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.
* 'miter': Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the miterLimit property.

Default value is 'bevel'. Refer to MDN [lineJoin][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineJoin

markLine.data.1.blur.lineStyle.miterLimi.desc:
>  Since > v5.0.0 To set the miter limit ratio. Only works when join is set as miter. Default value is 10. Negative、0、Infinity and NaN values are ignored. Refer to MDN [miterLimit][0] for more details.

[0]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/miterLimit

markArea.desc: Used to mark an area in chart. For example, mark a time interval.

markArea.silent.desc: Whether to ignore mouse events. Default value is false, for triggering and responding to mouse events.

markArea.label.position.desc:
Label position. **Followings are the options:*** [x, y] Use relative percentage, or absolute pixel values to represent position of label relative to top-left corner of bounding box. For example: 

      // Absolute pixel values
      position: [10, 10],
      // Relative percentage
      position: ['50%', '50%']
* 'top'
* 'left'
* 'right'
* 'bottom'
* 'inside'
* 'insideLeft'
* 'insideRight'
* 'insideTop'
* 'insideBottom'
* 'insideTopLeft'
* 'insideBottomLeft'
* 'insideTopRight'
* 'insideBottomRight'

See: [label position][0].

[0]: https://echarts.apache.org/examples/en/view.html?c=doc-example/label-position

markArea.label.distance.desc:
Distance to the host graphic element. It is valid only when position is string value (like 'top'、'insideRight'). See: [label position][0].

[0]: https://echarts.apache.org/examples/en/editor.html?c=doc-example/label-position

markArea.label.rotate.desc:
Rotate label, from -90 degree to 90, positive value represents rotate anti-clockwise. See: [label rotation][0].

[0]: https://echarts.apache.org/examples/en/editor.html?c=bar-label-rotation

markArea.label.offset.desc: Whether to move text slightly. For example: [30, 40] means move 30 horizontally and move 40 vertically.

markArea.label.rich.<style_name>.borderR.desc: Border radius of the text fragment.

markArea.label.rich.<style_name>.padding.desc:
Padding of the text fragment, for example: 

* padding: [3, 4, 5, 6]: represents padding of [top, right, bottom, left].
* padding: 4: represents padding: [4, 4, 4, 4].
* padding: [3, 4]: represents padding: [3, 4, 3, 4].

Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding.

markArea.label.rich.<style_name>.shadowC.desc: Shadow color of the text block.

markArea.label.rich.<style_name>.shadowB.desc: Show blur of the text block.

markArea.label.rich.<style_name>.shadowO.desc: Shadow X offset of the text block.
Shadow Y offset of the text block.

markArea.label.rich.<style_name>.width.desc: Width of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. In most cases, there is no need to specify it. You may want to use it in some cases like make simple table or using background image (see backgroundColor). Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding. width can also be percent string, like '100%', which represents the percent of contentWidth (that is, the width without padding) of its container box. It is based on contentWidth because that each text fragment is layout based on the content box, where it makes no sense that calculating width based on outerWith in prectice. Notice, width and height only work when rich specified.

markArea.label.rich.<style_name>.height.desc: Height of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. You may want to use it in some cases like using background image (see backgroundColor). Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding. Notice, width and height only work when rich specified.

markArea.label.rich.<style_name>.textBor.desc: Storke color of the text. If set as 'inherit', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.
Storke line width of the text.

Stroke line type of the text. Possible values are: 

* 'solid'
* 'dashed'
* 'dotted'

Since v5.0.0, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the [dash array][0] of the line. With textBorderDashOffset , we can make the line style more flexible. For example： 

    {
    
    textBorderType: [5, 10],
    
    textBorderDashOffset: 5
    }
